briefs.alkene:
Mechanism: Hydrogen adsorbs onto the metal surface, followed by the alkene.
Stereochemistry: Exclusively Syn-Addition (both H atoms add from the same side).
Note: Sensitive to steric hindrance at the double bond.
briefs.alkyne:
Scope: Reduces alkynes completely to Alkanes.
Intermediate: The alkene intermediate is not isolable under standard conditions as it reduces faster than the alkyne.
briefs.aldehyde:
Mechanism: Surface-catalyzed addition of H-H across the C=O pi bond.
Product: Primary Alcohol (R-CH2-OH).
Rate: Generally slower than C=C reduction.
briefs.ketone:
Mechanism: Similar to aldehydes, reduces C=O to CH-OH.
Stereochemistry: If a chiral center is formed, a Racemic Mixture is typically obtained.
briefs.acid_chloride:
Transformation: Reduces Acid Chlorides to Primary Alcohols.
Note: To stop at the aldehyde stage, a catalyst poison (like BaSO4/S - Rosenmund) is required.
briefs.carboxylic_acid:
No Reaction: The resonance-stabilized carbonyl of the acid is too inert for standard catalytic hydrogenation.
Reason: Catalyst often gets poisoned or the activation energy is too high.
briefs.ester:
Conditions: requires high temperature and pressure.
Product: Cleaves the ester to yield two alcohol molecules.
Efficiency: Not the preferred method for ester reduction (LiAlH4 is better).
briefs.nitro:
Industrial Use: Standard method for converting Nitroarenes to Anilines.
Condition: Often run in ethanol or acidic media.

briefs.alkyne:
Selectivity: Partially reduces alkynes to Alkenes only.
Stereochemistry: Syn-Addition leads primarily to the Cis (Z)-Alkene.
Poison: BaSO4/Quinoline decreases catalyst activity to prevent over-reduction to alkanes.
briefs.acid_chloride:
Name Reaction: Rosenmund Reduction.
Selectivity: Stops reduction at the Aldehyde stage.
Mechanism: The poison prevents the aldehyde from adsorbing strongly enough to be further reduced.

briefs.alkene:
Inert: Isolated C=C bonds are electron-rich and repel the nucleophilic hydride (Al-H bond).
Exception: Can reduce C=C if conjugated with a strong electron-withdrawing group (Michael Addition style).
briefs.aldehyde:
Mechanism: Nucleophilic attack of H- on the carbonyl carbon to form an alkoxide, followed by protonation.
Product: Primary Alcohol.
briefs.ketone:
Mechanism: H- attacks the Si- or Re-face of the carbonyl.
Stereochemistry: Creates a chiral center; typically produces a racemic mixture unless a chiral auxiliary is used.
briefs.carboxylic_acid:
Step 1: Deprotonation to carboxylate salt (vigorous H2 evolution).
Step 2: Reduction of the carboxylate (difficult, requires harsh conditions) to Primary Alcohol.
briefs.ester:
Mechanism: Nucleophilic Acyl Substitution followed by Nucleophilic Addition.
Outcome: Cleaves ester into two alcohols (one from acyl, one from alkoxy group).
Note: Requires anhydrous conditions.
briefs.amide:
Unique Transformation: Reduces C=O completely to CH2.
Mechanism: Unlike esters, the C-N bond is not broken. Product is an Amine.
briefs.nitrile:
Mechanism: Double addition of hydride to the C≡N triple bond.
Product: Primary Amine (-CH2NH2).
briefs.epoxide:
Regioselectivity: Hydride attacks the less substituted carbon (SN2-like).
Product: Ring opens to allow formation of the more substituted alcohol (after protonation).

briefs.acid_chloride:
Selectivity: The bulky t-butoxy groups sterically hinder the aluminum, making it less reactive.
Outcome: Reduces Acid Chlorides to Aldehydes and stops there.
Comparison: A chemical alternative to the Rosenmund Reduction.

briefs.aldehyde:
Selectivity: Chemoselective for Aldehydes/Ketones in the presence of Esters.
Solvent: Can be used in protic solvents (MeOH, EtOH), unlike LiAlH4.
briefs.ketone:
Mechanism: Nucleophilic addition of hydride to C=O.
Product: Secondary Alcohol.
Safety: Much safer and easier to handle than LiAlH4.
briefs.acid_chloride:
Reactivity: Reduces Acid Chlorides to Primary Alcohols.
Note: While possible, it's rarely used for this as acid chlorides react violently with the protic solvents typical for NaBH4.
briefs.ester:
No Reaction: NaBH4 is generally too mild to reduce the less reactive ester carbonyl.
Utility: Allows selective reduction of a ketone in an ester-containing molecule.

briefs.alkene:
Reaction: Hydroboration-Oxidation.
Regiochemistry: Anti-Markovnikov addition of H-OH.
Stereochemistry: Syn-addition of H-B bond.
briefs.carboxylic_acid:
Selectivity: Uniquely potent for Carboxylic Acids.
Mechanism: Coordinates to the carbonyl oxygen (Lewis Acid-Base), activating it for hydride transfer.
Note: Reduces Acids FASTER than esters or even ketones.
briefs.ester:
Reaction: Slow reduction to alcohols.
Mechanistic Note: Requires excess diborane. Not the primary use case.
briefs.amide:
Product: Reduces Amides to Amines.
Mechanism: Similar to LiAlH4, preserves the C-N bond.
briefs.acid_chloride: No Reaction: Does not effectively reduce acid chlorides.

briefs.alkyne: Trans-Reduction: Na in liquid NH3 reduces alkynes to TRANS-Alkenes (Anti-addition) via radical anion mechanism.

briefs.alkene: Birch Reduction: Reduces aromatic rings to 1,4-cyclohexadienes. Electron Donating Groups (EDG) keep double bond; EWG reduce.
briefs.alkyne: Trans-Alkene: Reduces internal alkynes to trans-alkenes stereoselectively.

briefs.nitro: Selective Reduction: Reduces Nitro group (-NO2) to Amine (-NH2). Useful in aromatic chemistry.
briefs.alkyl_halide: Reduction: Reduces halides to alkanes via electron transfer.

briefs.ketone: Deoxygenation: Reduces C=O to CH2. Limitation: Acidic conditions (HCl) - avoid acid-sensitive groups.

briefs.aldehyde: Deoxygenation: Reduces C=O completely to CH2 (Alkane) via hydrazone intermediate.
briefs.ketone: Deoxygenation: Reduces C=O to CH2. Advantage: Basic conditions - good for acid-sensitive substrates.

briefs.alkyl_halide: Grignard Formation: Reacts with alkyl halides to form Grignard Reagent (R-Mg-X).

briefs.aldehyde: Nucleophilic Addition: R- attacks carbonyl carbon. Protonation gives 2° Alcohol.
briefs.ketone: Nucleophilic Addition: R- attacks carbonyl. Gives 3° Alcohol. Careful of steric hindrance.
briefs.ester: Double Addition: Two equivalents of RMgX reactions. First ketone, then 3° Alcohol. Cannot stop at ketone.
briefs.carboxylic_acid: Acid-Base only: R- is a strong base. Deprotonates acid to carboxylate salt. No addition.
briefs.epoxide: Ring Opening: Attacks LESS substituted carbon (SN2 like). Extends carbon chain by 2.
briefs.alcohol: Acid-Base: Destroys reagent (R-H formed). Protect alcohols before using Grignard!

briefs.carboxylic_acid: Ketone Synthesis: Adds once to form dilithio salt. Hydrolysis gives Ketone (unlike Grignard).

briefs.acid_chloride: Ketone Synthesis: Selective reaction. Replaces Cl with R group. Stops at Ketone (does not react with ketone product).
briefs.alkyl_halide: Corey-House Synthesis: Coupling reaction to form alkanes (R-R').
